questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding innervation of the uterus? (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Sensory level is from T10 to L1

options.label: B
options.text: Uterine contractility is mediated by innervations from level T7 - T8

options.label: C
options.text: In the 1st stage of labor, pain is due to the fibers at level of T10 - L1

options.label: D
options.text: In early labor, pain is usually because of the uterine contraction

questions.correct_answer: B. Uterine contractility is mediated by innervations from level T7 - T8
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Uterine contractility is mediated by innervations from level T7 - T8

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The incorrect statement regarding the innervation of the uterus is option B. Uterine contractility is primarily mediated by hormonal mechanisms rather than by specific spinal innervations. Hormones such as estrogen, prostaglandins, and oxytocin play a significant role in inducing uterine contractions, while progesterone helps maintain uterine relaxation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Sensory level is from T10 to L1: The sensory innervation of the uterus is indeed from spinal levels T10 to L1. These afferent fibers enter the spinal cord via the inferior hypogastric plexus and are responsible for transmitting sensory information from the uterus.
  • • Option A. Sensory level is from T10 to L1:
  • • Option C. In the 1st stage of labor, pain is due to the fibers at level of T10 - L1: During the 1st stage of labor, pain is mediated by spinal segments T10 to L1. This pain is due to the distension of the cervix and lower uterine segment, as well as the contraction of the uterus.
  • • Option C. In the 1st stage of labor, pain is due to the fibers at level of T10 - L1:
  • • Option D. In early labor, pain is usually because of the uterine contraction: In early labor, pain is usually related to uterine contractions, which stimulate nociceptors in the genital tract and can cause discomfort and pain.
  • • Option D. In early labor, pain is usually because of the uterine contraction:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Uterine contractility is not mediated by innervations from spinal level T7 - T8; instead, it is primarily influenced by hormonal mechanisms.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 500, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 500, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8 th edition

questions.text: Drug resistance is seen in which of the following STDs: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Gonorrhea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the causative agent of gonorrhea, has developed resistance to multiple antibiotics, including penicillin and fluoroquinolones, making third-generation cephalosporins the current treatment of choice.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most effective drug in smoking cessation?( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Varenicline

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Varenicline is the most effective medication for smoking cessation. It works as a partial agonist at nicotinic receptors, helping to alleviate withdrawal symptoms and reduce the rewarding effects of nicotine. This makes it a highly effective option for individuals seeking to quit smoking.

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibition given in the graph? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Non-competitive

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given graph illustrates non-competitive inhibition, where the inhibitor binds to an allosteric site, causing a decrease in Vmax while Km remains constant. This type of inhibition affects the enzyme's activity without altering the substrate's binding affinity.

questions.text: Which of the following drug reduces mortality in COVID-19 patients? ( INICET Nov 2020) A. Dexamethasone B. Remdesivir C. Favipiravir
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Only A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dexamethasone is the only drug among the listed options that has been shown to reduce mortality in severe COVID-19 cases, due to its potent anti-inflammatory effects. Remdesivir and favipiravir have not demonstrated a mortality benefit.
  • ➤ Dexamethasone

questions.text: The vector shown in the image below transmits which of the following organism? ( INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Orientia tsutsugamushi

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The trombiculid mite, particularly in its larval stage called a chigger, transmits Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus.
  • ➤ The trombiculid mite, particularly in its larval stage called a chigger, transmits Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus.

questions.text: The Thymus gland is specialized in identifying the molecules of the Major Histocompatibility Complex that are presented to it. It discerns whether these cells belong to the body's own or are of foreign origin. Which specific gene is accountable for this function? ( INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) AIRE

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The AIRE gene is crucial for promoting self-tolerance by ensuring that developing T cells in the thymus are exposed to self-antigens, thus preventing autoimmune diseases.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes in with primary amenorrhea and indications of virilization. She displays underdeveloped breasts and pubic hair consistent with prepubertal stages, rated at Tanner stage 2. She has a closed-off vaginal canal and noticeable enlargement of the clitoris. Despite her female sex, her testosterone levels are within the male range. Her genetic makeup is 46XY. What is the likely medical diagnosis in this case? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 5 alpha reductase deficiency

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given scenario points to a diagnosis of 5 alpha reductase deficiency.
  • • 5 alpha reductase deficiency causes inability to convert testosterone to DHT.
  • • When DHT levels are low, newborns will possess external genitalia with a feminine appearance. These youngsters are commonly brought up as girls until they reach puberty, at which point they begin to display signs of masculinization due to the influence of testosterone. As a result, clitoromegaly becomes evident. The absence of estrogen conversion from testosterone results in limited breast growth. Scanty pubic hair is observed since its growth is contingent on both testosterone and dihydrotestosterone.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. 17 alpha hydroxylase deficiency : Leads to reduced formation of corticosteroids, sex hormones and increased mineralocorticoids (causing hypokalemia and hypertension). Patient with XY chromosome presents with atypical genitalia and undescended testes. Patient with XX chromosome lacks secondary sexual development.
  • • Option B. 17 alpha hydroxylase deficiency
  • • Option C. Androgen insensitivity syndrome : Defect in androgen receptor resulting in female-appearing genetic male (46, XY); female external genitalia with scant axillary and pubic hair, rudimentary vagina; uterus and fallopian tubes absent due to persistence of anti-Mullerian hormone from testes. Patients develop normal functioning testes. Patient has increased testosterone, estrogen & LH as compared to other sex chromosome disorders.
  • • Option C. Androgen insensitivity syndrome
  • • Option D. Swyer syndrome : 46 XY gonadal dysgenesis; Absent secondary sexual characters, but normal female internal and external genitalia. Gonadectomy needs to be done.
  • • Option D. Swyer syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ 5-alpha reductase deficiency causes primary amenorrhea and virilization in genetic females (46XY), resulting in the inability to convert testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT). This leads to female external genitalia at birth and masculinization at puberty, with signs such as clitoromegaly and underdeveloped breasts.

questions.text: Organize the subsequent structures in the auditory pathway, beginning from the receptors and moving towards the cortex: ( INICET May 2023) Auditory Cortex Spiral ganglion Cochlear Nucleus Lateral leminiscus Inferior colliculus Olivary complex Medial geniculate body
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 2-3-6-4-5-7-1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ AUDITORY PATHWAY
  • ➤ AUDITORY PATHWAY
  • ➤ E – Eighth nerve
  • ➤ C – Cochlear nucleus
  • ➤ O – Olivary complex (superior)
  • ➤ L – Lateral lemniscus
  • ➤ I – Inferior colliculus
  • ➤ M – Medial geniculate body
  • ➤ A – Auditory cortex

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Factor V Leiden mutation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited cause of thrombophilia.
  • ➤ Factor V Leiden mutation

questions.text: Which of the following drugs in leprosy treatment cause hyperpigmentation? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Clofazimine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Clofazimine is an antimicrobial agent used primarily in the treatment of leprosy. One of the notable side effects of clofazimine is skin pigmentation changes, which can manifest as hyperpigmentation. This occurs because clofazimine accumulates in the skin, leading to discoloration. The pigmentation typically appears as a reddish or brownish coloration and can be distressing for patients due to its noticeable cosmetic impact. The pigmentation is long-lasting and may take several months to years to fade after discontinuation of the drug.
  • • Clofazimine is an antimicrobial agent used primarily in the treatment of leprosy.
  • • One of the notable side effects of clofazimine is skin pigmentation changes, which can manifest as hyperpigmentation.
  • • This occurs because clofazimine accumulates in the skin, leading to discoloration.
  • • The pigmentation typically appears as a reddish or brownish coloration and can be distressing for patients due to its noticeable cosmetic impact.
  • • The pigmentation is long-lasting and may take several months to years to fade after discontinuation of the drug.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Dapsone: Dapsone is another drug used in the treatment of leprosy, but it does not cause hyperpigmentation. Its side effects include hemolysis and methemoglobinemia, especially in individuals with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.
  • • Option A. Dapsone:
  • • Option B. Ofloxacin: Ofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic used to treat various bacterial infections, including leprosy, but it is not associated with hyperpigmentation. Its common side effects include gastrointestinal disturbances and tendonitis.
  • • Option B. Ofloxacin:
  • • Option C. Rifampicin: Rifampicin is an antibiotic used to treat several bacterial infections, including leprosy. It can cause reddish-orange discoloration of bodily fluids like urine, sweat, and tears but does not cause hyperpigmentation of the skin.
  • • Option C. Rifampicin:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clofazimine is a drug used in leprosy treatment that can cause significant and long-lasting hyperpigmentation of the skin.

questions.text: An elderly woman presented with symptoms of confusion, thirst, and abdominal pain. On examination, she had pallor and thoracic spine tenderness. X-ray spine showed osteolytic lesions. Her lab investigations showed the following findings: Hb - 6.9g/dL, WBC 4000/cm3 with normal differential count, Serum calcium 13mg/dL, Creatinine 2.3mg/dL, Total protein 9g/dL, Albumin 2.4g/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

questions.text: To which organism does the provided image of the cell wall belong? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:

questions.text: Calculate for Burn Surface Area (BSA) for a patent with burn involving the chest and abdomen right arm and right thigh (circumferental): (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 31.5%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The Rule of Nines is a method used to estimate the total body surface area affected by burns. It divides the body into sections that represent approximately 9% of the total surface area, facilitating quick and effective assessment and treatment planning for burn patients.

questions.text: Which of the following is a true association related to HRT (Hormone replacement therapy) among the options provided? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.correct_answer: A. Decreases risk of Colon cancer
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Decreases risk of Colon cancer

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) has been associated with a decreased risk of colon cancer. Studies have shown that estrogen in HRT may have a protective effect against the development of colon cancer. This effect is believed to be related to estrogen’s impact on gastrointestinal mucosal growth and repair.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option B. Decreased risk of breast cancer: This option is incorrect. HRT, particularly with estrogen and progestin, is associated with an increased risk of breast cancer. Long-term use of combined HRT has been shown to elevate the risk of breast cancer in several studies.
  • • Option B. Decreased risk of breast cancer:
  • • Option C. Decreased risk of endometrial cancer: This option is incorrect. Unopposed estrogen (estrogen alone without progestin) increases the risk of endometrial cancer. To mitigate this risk, progestin is often added to HRT in women with an intact uterus.
  • • Option C. Decreased risk of endometrial cancer:
  • • Option D. Increases risk of osteoporosis: This option is incorrect. HRT is actually used prophylactically to reduce the risk of osteoporosis. Estrogen helps maintain bone density and prevent bone loss, which is beneficial in managing osteoporosis.
  • • Option D. Increases risk of osteoporosis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) decreases the risk of colon cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following does not have polysaccharide vaccine? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hepatitis B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant vaccine, not a polysaccharide vaccine, as it targets a virus that does not have a polysaccharide capsule.

questions.text: A child is diagnosed with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, which among the following will not be seen in this child? (AIIMS NOV 2020)

options.label: B
options.text: Visible peristalsis from left to right

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bilious vomiting

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CHPS (congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis) is most commonly seen in infants between 2 to 8 weeks of age. It is caused by the hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the Pylorus, which results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet. First-born male infants are at the highest risk for developing CHPS. Projectile, non-bilious vomiting is a common symptom in infants with CHPS. A palpable olive-shaped mass is usually felt in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium, and visible peristalsis can be observed moving from left to right, followed by projectile vomiting. Infants with CHPS develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality including hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria. Loss of hydrochloric acid leads to metabolic alkalosis and hypochloremia due to persistent vomiting. The kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3, but the loss of sodium stimulates aldosterone secretion leading to the loss of potassium ions (hypokalemia). Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in paradoxical aciduria. Treatment involves rehydration and correction of metabolic abnormalities before surgery, and the Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the standard surgical procedure for CHPS.
  • ➤ CHPS (congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis) is most commonly seen in infants between 2 to 8 weeks of age.
  • ➤ It is caused by the hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the Pylorus, which results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet.
  • ➤ First-born male infants are at the highest risk for developing CHPS.
  • ➤ Projectile, non-bilious vomiting is a common symptom in infants with CHPS.
  • ➤ A palpable olive-shaped mass is usually felt in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium, and visible peristalsis can be observed moving from left to right, followed by projectile vomiting.
  • ➤ Infants with CHPS develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality including hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.
  • ➤ Loss of hydrochloric acid leads to metabolic alkalosis and hypochloremia due to persistent vomiting.
  • ➤ The kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3, but the loss of sodium stimulates aldosterone secretion leading to the loss of potassium ions (hypokalemia).
  • ➤ Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in paradoxical aciduria.
  • ➤ Treatment involves rehydration and correction of metabolic abnormalities before surgery, and the Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the standard surgical procedure for CHPS.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate definition of stress? ( INICET Nov 2022)

options.label: C
options.text: It is the body's response to anything that requires attention or action causing physical, emotional, or psychological strain

questions.correct_answer: C. It is the body's response to anything that requires attention or action causing physical, emotional, or psychological strain
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is the body's response to anything that requires attention or action causing physical, emotional, or psychological strain.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Stress can be conceptualized as the body's adaptive response to demands or threats. It's not just a psychological phenomenon; it has physiological correlates as well. Stressors can be external (e.g., environmental pressures) or internal (e.g., illness, or undergoing a medical procedure), and they can be short-lived (acute) or long-term (chronic).

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 2117

questions.text: A patient comes with palpitation to ER. His Pulse-180/min and BP-70mm of Hg systolic. ECG shows narrow QRS complex tachycardia with regular heart rate. What is the next step in management? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) DC cardioversion

questions.text: A woman presents with impaired hearing. Her audiometry findings are given below: ( INICET Nov 2021) Pick the right combination of tuning fork test results that would be seen in this patient. (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to right ear

options.label: D
options.text: Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to left ear

questions.correct_answer: C. Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to right ear
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Left Rinne’s test positive, Weber’s test lateralized to right ear

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In sensorineural hearing loss, Rinne's test remains positive, and Weber's test lateralizes to the better-hearing ear. The provided audiogram indicates left-sided SNHL, resulting in a positive Rinne test on the left and Weber lateralizing to the right ear.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 24, 25
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 24, 25

questions.explanation:
Ans.

questions.explanation: Ans. A) Veress needle

questions.text: Double bleb sign seen in early pregnancy is due to? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.correct_answer: C. Yolk sac and amniotic sac
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Yolk sac and amniotic sac

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The double bleb sign is due to the yolk sac and amniotic sac.
  • • On USG, gestational sac contains the yolk sac and amniotic sac which appear as two small bubbles known as the double bleb sign.
  • • It is seen at 7.5 – 8 weeks.
  • • Do not confuse with Double decidual sign
  • • Double decidual sign
  • • Double decidual sign – true gestational sac surrounded by two layers – decidua capsularis and decidua parietalis with fluid collection in between.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Twin pregnancy: This would involve two separate gestational sacs or distinct embryonic structures in a single sac, not the double bleb sign of a single gestational sac.
  • • Option A. Twin pregnancy:
  • • Option B. Amnion and chorion: These are two layers surrounding the embryo, but the double bleb sign specifically refers to the early visualization of the yolk sac and amniotic sac.
  • • Option B. Amnion and chorion:
  • • Option D. Heterotopic pregnancy: Involves simultaneous intrauterine and extrauterine pregnancies. This would not specifically relate to the double bleb sign, which is a normal ultrasound finding in a single intrauterine pregnancy.
  • • Option D. Heterotopic pregnancy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The double bleb sign is a normal ultrasound finding in early pregnancy, showing the presence of both the yolk sac and the amniotic sac within the gestational sac, important for confirming a normal early intrauterine pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following STD is transmitted by all components of the blood? (INICET MAY 2024)

questions.text: A patient was treated for peptic ulcer with an H. pylori regimen. Which of the following is used to assess the success of treatment? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  C) Urea breath test

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Wobble hypothesis is due to which property of the codon?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Degeneracy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The wobble hypothesis is primarily due to the degeneracy of the genetic code, allowing multiple codons to code for the same amino acid, with variation in the third (wobble) position of the codon.
  • ➤ Wobble bases
  • ➤ Wobble bases
  • ➤ 3rd base of the codon on mRNA and 1 st base of anticodon on tRNA in 5’ to 3’ direction are wobble positions.
  • ➤ Wobble hypothesis says that for binding between bases present in these positions, some imprecision is allowed. i.e. one base in anticodon can bind with various bases of codon. This is also called as degeneracy of codon i.e. There is more than one codon for one amino acid. So, Wobble hypothesis is due to degeneracy of codons.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is true regarding the course of the mandibular nerve? (INICET NOV 2022) Auriculotemporal nerve is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it emerges from behind the temporomandibular joint. Buccal branch is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it emerges from behind the mandibular ramus. Lingual nerve is a branch from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it arcs around the submandibular duct. Ophthalmic nerve is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it arises in the middle cranial fossa.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. 2,3

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Correct Statements:
  • • Correct Statements:
  • • Statement 2 : True. The buccal branch, which is indeed a branch of the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, emerges from behind the mandibular ramus. This nerve primarily supplies sensory innervation to the skin over the cheek and buccal mucosa.
  • • Statement 2
  • • Statement 3: True. The lingual nerve, a branch from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve, is responsible for providing sensory innervation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. It famously arcs around the submandibular duct, a notable anatomical feature.
  • • Statement 3:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Statement 1 : Incorrect. The auriculotemporal nerve actually arises from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve, not the anterior division, and it does indeed emerge from behind the temporomandibular joint.
  • • Statement 1
  • • Statement 4: Incorrect. The ophthalmic nerve is not a branch of the mandibular nerve. Instead, it is an independent division of the trigeminal nerve (V1), originating from the trigeminal ganglion located in the middle cranial fossa. It is responsible for providing sensory innervation to the forehead, scalp, and parts of the eye.
  • • Statement 4:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The mandibular nerve's complex branching includes both sensory and motor components that are essential for facial sensation and movements. Understanding its branches, such as the buccal and lingual nerves, and their courses, is critical in dental, surgical, and diagnostic practices.

  • ➤ Pedicle of the vertebra is the area used to fixate the screws through during the spine straightening surgeries for scoliosis.

  • ➤ Pedicle of the vertebra is the area used to fixate the screws through during the spine straightening surgeries for scoliosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented in OPD with a swelling in his neck. Given below is the histopathological image. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: The active metabolite of cyclophosphamide is: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. 4 - hydroxy cyclophosphamide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cyclophosphamide's therapeutic effects are primarily due to its active metabolite, 4-hydroxy cyclophosphamide. It is important to manage the side effects of cyclophosphamide, particularly hemorrhagic cystitis, through the use of mesna and adequate hydration. Pulmonary fibrosis and bone marrow suppression are other significant side effects to be monitored during treatment.

questions.text: Match the following? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Each infectious disease has a specific staining technique for identification: Malaria (Giemsa stain), Tuberculosis (ZN stain), Leprosy (Fite Faraco stain), and Actinomycosis (Gram stain).

questions.text: Which of the following methods uses RNA? ( INICET May 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) RT-PCR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ RT-PCR is a method for detection of gene expression using reverse transcription of RNA to synthesize cDNA. Western Blot most commonly involve antigen-antibody interactions which is a.protein-protein interaction. Sanger’s method is a DNA sequencing technique by chain termination of DNA polymerization using DNA as template. G-banding is a chromosomal staining technique usually done for karyotyping analysis and involve only DNA.
  • ➤ Ref- Lehninger 6 th e/p 331
  • ➤ Ref-
  • ➤ Lehninger 6 th e/p
  • ➤ 331

questions.text: Under which circumstances is live vaccination not contraindicated? ( INICET MAY 2023) DiGeorge syndrome Wiskott Aldrich Syndrome Ataxia telangiectasia Complement deficiency
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 4 only

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Complement deficiency does not pose a contraindication for live vaccination.
  • ➤ However, it is important to note that live vaccines should be avoided in individuals with DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome, and Ataxia telangiectasia, because these are immunodeficiency disorders.

questions.text: Identify the fracture site in the X-ray shown below. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 4th, 5th, 6th rib

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When identifying rib fractures on a chest X-ray, start counting from the first rib, which is located just beneath the clavicle, and follow downward. Note the curvature of the ribs: anterior ribs curve downward and outward, while posterior ribs curve upward. This method helps in accurately locating and identifying the specific ribs involved in fractures or other abnormalities.

questions.text: Which of the following is not typically associated with Autoimmune Polyendocrine Syndrome Type 1 (APS-1)? (INICET NOV 2024)

options.label: B
options.text: Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus association is high

options.label: C
options.text: Association with mucocutaneous candidiasis is high

questions.correct_answer: B. Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus association is high
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus association is high

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Classic triad of APS-1:
  • ➤ Mucocutaneous candidiasis (most common and earliest manifestation) Hypoparathyroidism Addison's disease
  • ➤ Mucocutaneous candidiasis (most common and earliest manifestation)
  • ➤ Hypoparathyroidism
  • ➤ Addison's disease

questions.text: Jackson Rees circuit is used in: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pediatric controlled ventilation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Jackson Rees circuit (Mapleson F) is specifically designed and used for pediatric anesthesia, suitable for both spontaneous and controlled ventilation.

questions.text: All of the following side effects are more commonly seen with carbamazepine than oxcarbazepine, except: ( INICET Nov 2022)

options.label: D
options.text: Elevated levels of gamma glutamyl transpeptidas

questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Hyponatremia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hyponatremia is more commonly associated with oxcarbazepine than carbamazepine. While both drugs can cause similar side effects due to their similar mechanisms of action, certain adverse effects, such as hypotension, rash, and elevated GGT levels, are more frequently seen with carbamazepine.

questions.text: A genetic counsellor is discussing various types of genetic tests with a couple planning for a child. Which of the following statements accurately describes genetic screening? (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Screening tests define risk of passing genetic disorder

options.label: B
options.text: Screening tests are more accurate than diagnostic tests

questions.correct_answer: A. Screening tests define risk of passing genetic disorder
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Screening tests define risk of passing genetic disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Genetic screening tests are used to define the risk of passing on a genetic disorder and can help determine the likelihood of developing a genetic condition. They are not as definitive as diagnostic tests and do not necessarily involve invasive procedures or genetic mapping.
  • ➤ Genetic screening tests are used to define the risk of passing on a genetic disorder and can help determine the likelihood of developing a genetic condition.
  • ➤ They are not as definitive as diagnostic tests and do not necessarily involve invasive procedures or genetic mapping.

questions.text: Eicosanoids are formed from:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Eicosanoids are bioactive lipid molecules that play a crucial role in various physiological processes in the body. They are formed from arachidonic acid. Arachidonic acid has (20 C, 4=) and is synthesized from linoleic acid. Eicosanoids (Prostaglandins and leukotrienes) are synthesized from arachidonic acid. So, Linoleic acid is considered as most essential fatty acid.
  • ➤ Extra Information on PUFAs
  • ➤ Extra Information on PUFAs

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 224

questions.text: For the diagnosis of resistant hypertension, the patient should have uncontrolled hypertension despite taking three antihypertensive drugs. This should include at least one? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The diagnostic criteria for resistant hypertension include having blood pressure above target despite taking three drugs, one of which must be a diuretic, OR having controlled blood pressure with four or more drugs. Typically, a thiazide diuretic is used in the setting of hypertension.

questions.text: Which of the following is not useful for hemoglobin estimation by the colorimetric test? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) RBC pipette

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The RBC pipette is not useful for hemoglobin estimation by the colorimetric (Sahli's) method, as it is designed for cell counting rather than for the preparation and color comparison required in this test.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child was operated for a tumour in the lower end of femur. The gross specimen of the resected tumour is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INCET MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given image in the question shows a cut section of osteosarcoma of the femur. The destructive tumor arises from the metaphysis, with extensive involvement of the marrow cavity and extension into soft tissue.
  • ➤ The given image in the question shows a cut section of osteosarcoma of the femur.
  • ➤ The destructive tumor arises from the metaphysis, with extensive involvement of the marrow cavity and extension into soft tissue.
